posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked: Hi I am a member of a FRC team I am a freshman and the only girl on the Team. I want to know how do I start programming. As the only female member on the team it’s always so hard for me to ask questions. I want to know what is the most efficient programming language for the robot and how do I start learning. So please feel free to share any resources it would be a great help for me. I would also like to know how do I encourage girls in high school to join robotics.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Outreach Head I Media Head I Programmer I Cad Desiginer

posts.custom_user_title: Outreach Head I Media Head I Programmer I Cad Desiginer

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Most efficient language is probably not java, but I would recommend learning java. It has a lot more documentation and is used by a majority of teams so it’ll be the easiest to get a grasp of.

Here’s a website to learn some basic programming:

FRCLadder is a platform that provides a comprehensive course on robotics programming specifically designed for participants of the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). Whether you're a beginner or an experienced programmer, our course covers all the...

link_counts.title: FRCLadder: Learning Platform for FIRST Robotics Competition

posts.name: Joshua Epperson
posts.cooked: Look at other teams codes and join the unofficial discord server for FRC . Theres a programming-help channel where you can ask questions and get answers pretty fast. In regards to getting more women in robotics, it’s mainly about fostering an inclusive environment. That goes for getting anyone in FRC in general aswell.

posts.name: Ben Bernard (He/Him)
posts.cooked:
Hopefully other folks will reply to the team dynamics aspect of your question, so I’m going to focus on the pragmatic.  I see that your team has used Java in the past, so that  seems like a natural place to start.  There are a number of resources out there for learning Java, and the FRC docs provide a good overview of robot programming at Software Component Overview — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation .   The programming forum here on CD has a lot of  links to different teams’ codebases, so reviewing those is a good approach.

Lastly, don’t be afraid to ask questions here!  You may not always get quick answers, but I’m continually impressed with the degree to which the FRC community steps up to help new members.

link_counts.title: Software Component Overview — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Tyson Whelan
posts.cooked:
Unless your team is a rookie, I’d assume they already have a language that they use for the robot. Ask your team what language they use, get familiar with the basics of it then look over some of your team’s code from previous years if they have some. This will help you understand some of the standards, naming conventions, etc. that they use.

Also looking at the WPILib documentation . This is the main library that is used for programming the robot and has tons of useful examples that you are going to need when programming the robot.

link_counts.title: FIRST Robotics Competition Control System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: I won’t repeat the things that have already been said, but I thought I’d mention some great Youtube tutorials for specifically FRC programming in Java. Personally, I really liked Command Based Framework by Manning Robotics and Zero to Autonomous, which really helped me understand the whole framework for programming in FRC .

posts.name: MrNick
posts.cooked:
I would recommend Java as a programming language unless you have reasons why you want to use something else. Java is used by the vast majority of teams and has many available resources. So, unless you have a strong desire to use a different language that you are much more comfortable with, I would go with Java. I would echo recommendations for reading through the wpilib documentation. I would specifically recommend the sections on command based programming. They are extremely helpful in understanding how the robot code can be organized.

This sequence of articles serves as an introduction to and reference for the WPILib command-based framework. For a collection of example projects using the command-based framework, see Command-Base...

If a summer project would help you to learn, I would recommend acquiring an XRP. This will help you learn Java, WPILib, and all about programming an FRC robot.

The XRP is a small and inexpensive robot designed for learning about programming FRC robots. All the same tools used for programming full-sized FRC robots can be used to program the XRP. The XRP co...

link_counts.title: Getting Started with XRP — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Command-Based Programming — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
As the only female member on the team it’s always so hard for me to ask questions.

This risks segueing from the point of this thread, but please talk with your team mentors (or at least one who you trust) about this. We can help you learn on CD , but you’ll need a good relationship with your team to actually apply your knowledge IRL.

posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked:
AVHon:

you’ll need a good relationship with your team

It’s always been a challenge for me to communicate with my team because all the female members of the team left because of some or the other reason. Now I am the only one left and there is always a lot of miscommunication within me and my team. And  this is my rookie year in the robotics club so nobody really cares if I join or leave because my presence doesn’t really matter in the team. Currently I am working on the media side of robotics, when the year started I was very much interested in the programming and the build department but because the club had a lot of boys in the group it was not easy for me to communicate with the team members. It took a total five months to communicate with the club president because of the awkwardness. Then during January the new game was announced and shortly after that the major female member the vice president left robotics, and then the very next day another female member the Media Head left robotics. Then I decided to continue robotics because I don’t want to be a quitter but a person who wanted to suffer and learn robotics. The first few days went well for us but after sometime some of the guys started behaving rude towards me. When ever I tried to communicate about things going on it was awkward. I decided to leave robotics temporarily and come back with a fresh start. When I came back after a two weeks break it was fine and that was the first time I communicated with the club president and decided to join robotics and make buttons/pins when I was making the buttons it was so awful to communicate and ask for help if I am stuck. I got a comment that the buttons I made were simple and ordinary that wasn’t okay for me. During the competition I had a really bad mental breakdown during the competition. So, the culture of our team is toxic and unchangeable.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Outreach Head I Media Head I Programmer I Cad Desiginer

posts.custom_user_title: Outreach Head I Media Head I Programmer I Cad Desiginer

posts.cooked:
Hey there, my name is Asha

I am a current sophomore on my team, but I joined as a freshmen, where I was our only female programmer (Still am, actually).  Like you, my rookie year was also quite turbulent because of this situation.

From reading your posts, I can see that there are quite serious cultural issues on your team that extend beyond normal inter-team conflict. Situations like these can be very hard or even impossible to resolve if you don’t have the right support.

I am here to say that you don’t owe your team your mental health. If you are at the point where you are having mental breakdowns at competitions, that’s a good sign you need to step back for a while and focus on your wellbeing. This does not make you a quitter. In fact, doing this will mean you have not given up on your needs and are willing to do hard things because of that.

Trying to learn to program well, is like learning three languages at once.  There’s the syntax of a given language, there’s the logical sequencing of source code (algorithmically solving the problem), and then there’s the design of how to solve the problem.

The last one is the hardest, and only comes with experience.  The second one is normally an argument between you and your IDE as to how the code is written.  The first one is the building blocks of the language.

It is more than okay that you are struggling, especially considering your team environment. It is difficult.

I know that it probaly hurts badly right now, and its not as easy as I’m making out to be. If you want to be in robotics, you deserve to be with people who will value and respect you. My DMs are open if you would like to talk futher.

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked:
Hey there. I was the only girl on my team when I was a student and I still find myself being the only girl in the room more often than not at work - comes with the territory of being a controls engineer I suppose.

That said - to echo Asha - you shouldn’t be in a place where you’re so stressed you’re having mental breakdowns or feeling awkward. FIRST is supposed to be fun! In fact, it’s a core value.

Do you have a mentor or other trusted adult on your team that you can talk to? Your team should be embracing and teaching new members, not making you feel unwelcome.

Edit: Just noticed your team number. You’re local to me. If you’re ever at a competition (ARL perhaps?) come find any of us female volunteers if you ever need anything.

posts.name: Kendree C
posts.cooked:
Hi, another former only-girl-on-robotics-team here. I sympathize with what you’re going through and I’m here if you need someone to talk to.

My FRC career started a bit like yours. My team wasn’t sexist or anything, but being the only girl still gave me the feeling sometimes that I didn’t belong on the team. Heck, I spent most of the time thinking I wasn’t smart enough for programming. I managed to learn the ropes by just spending a lot of time doing robotics, reading chiefdelphi OA threads and software documentation. This helped me contribute more to the team; this year I’m programming lead (and the other technical subteams lead). The point of this story is that it can be very possible to turn things around; all you need is some time to learn. But I would encourage you to seriously think about whether your team will treat you well enough for it to be worth it. It’s really hard to build yourself up if your team is going to be pushing you down. If that is the case, it might be better to leave that environment and use your time somewhere more worthwhile.

By the way, if you decide it is worth your time to learn FRC programming, the WPILib docs are a great place to start, as I think has been linked above. I’d also be happy to be a remote programming “mentor” because the docs can be very overwhelming at first.

And about recruiting more girls (because yes, happy to say I am a former only-girl-on-the team, not a current one…) sometimes there just aren’t any girls interested in joining, which you unfortunately can’t change. But our team did manage to bump up from 1 girl (me) last year to ~30% female active members this year, and according to a couple of female rookies this year, it helped them to have a girl already on the team who understood their perspectives and made sure their voices were heard. It’s tough starting out on a team where there isn’t the support of a female veteran, but if you’re on the team now you can become that person. All it takes is a little more experience and a little confidence, and we’re all here to help you succeed.

Please don’t hesitate to reach out! –Kendree

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked:
I strongly suggest learning java through codecademy. It’s an online course and really helpful.

It’s free if you make the account with your school email.

I’d start with Java. There is a ton of support for Java stuff in FRC . As someone who will likely be doing a lot of programming next year I can heavily relate. Does your school offer AP Computer Science? If it does id say take that (As much as I dislike the College Bored). I took that class this year (the 2023-2024 school year), and coming from very limited coding experience, it helped familiarize me with the some of the formatting of java and has been a huge help in letting me understand (for the most part) what our lead programmer is typing.

If you have absolutely no coding experience, id start with a block coding challenge (like one of the ones offered on Code.org ). I struggled for a long time in thinking that they wouldn’t teach me anything about how a robot functions, but they do a pretty good job at teaching one the basics of programming languages (functions/methods, arrays, data types). Plus, depending on which one you select it can get you kinda familiar with the object oriented approach that FRC robots use.

Resources that other people will link will definitely be helpful in your programming journey. The biggest thing I think to get started is to understand how a programming language functions. Most of the more used languages are somewhat similar in how they operate with data (some super experience programmers may tell you otherwise). Another place you might go, if you choose to learn java and once you somewhat understand how the syntax (style) of java works, is CodingBat (Note: these problems will definitely make you want to bang your head against a wall sometimes, but it really helps reinforce the syntax and how some data types work).

As for how to encourage more girls to join the team, it really depends. I think having a girl on the team already is a huge part of improving the diversity of your team. For instance, our team just two years ago had only one girl, currently our team has six. Thats all I can offer in that regard. I don’t want to offer incorrect advice. (as I am not a girl) I don’t have much experience with situations like yours, advice with that is probably more helpful coming from people who are better positioned to give it, like the stuff @asha_forever , @Notquitebananas , and @kchenturtles have given so far.
